description: This course is concerned with how and why people behave as consumers. Its goals are to: (1) provide conceptual understanding of consumer behavior, (2) provide experience in the application of buyer behavior concepts to marketing management decisions and social policy decision-making; and (3) to develop analytical capability in using behavioral research.
name: CONSUMER BEHAVIOR

values.comments: Students in Marketing 211 enjoyed the enthusiasm, accessibility and energy of professor Bolton even if the course material was at times a bit dull.  Bolton’s use of video increased student’s interest and excitement about the material.   The professor did a mid-semester review and responded well to the feedback making visible improvements to the course and her teaching approach.  Some of the international students in the course noted that the examples used in class to illustrate course material were not as well known to or easily understood by them in comparison with the American students.

States one of the students in Marketing 211 with professor Deborah Small, “It was refreshing to have a teaching team (professor and TA) that really loved the topic of the course.  Their passion showed!”  Other students reflected that the professor and TA were both very helpful and motivating for them.  The range of topics covered in and guest speakers invited to the class were also interesting for the students.  Most unsatisfactory remarks were regarding the project for the course which the students found to be less than helpful in reinforcing the main course concepts and for which the guidelines were not clear enough.
